body_html:
@Bahramudin : GPU on Windows isn't packaged yet (see #16660), but as @aselle said, we do support it it for Linux.

@szaza : To use GPU on Linux, your dependencies should look like this. From a cursory look at your build.gradle, it would be a two line change:

  • Change line 15 to name: 'libtensorflow'
  • Change line 16 to name: 'libtensorflow_jni_gpu'

(Note the org.tensorflow:tensorflow artifact is a convenience one that pulls in libtensorflow and libtensorflow_jni)

Hope that helps.
Closing this since I believe the question is answered, but let me know if I'm mistaken.

Change line 16 to name: 'libtensorflow_jni_gpu'

body:
@Bahramudin : GPU on Windows isn't packaged yet (see #16660), but as @aselle said, we do support it it for Linux.

@szaza : To use GPU on Linux, your dependencies should look [like this](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vQ6DzxNTBrJo7K5P8t5_rBRGnyJoPUPBVOJR4ooHCwi4TlBFnIriFmI719rDNpcQzojqsV58aUqmBBx/pub?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000&slide=id.g306175dd89_0_41). From a cursory look at [your `build.gradle`](https://github.com/szaza/tensorflow-example-java/blob/9c69b58/build.gradle), it would be a two line change:
- Change line 15 to `name: 'libtensorflow'`
- Change line 16 to `name: 'libtensorflow_jni_gpu'`

(Note the `org.tensorflow:tensorflow` artifact is a convenience one that pulls in `libtensorflow` and `libtensorflow_jni`)

Hope that helps.
Closing this since I believe the question is answered, but let me know if I'm mistaken.
